rr.tool
Class Tool

java.lang.Object
  rr.tool.Tool
Direct Known Subclasses:
CountTool, EmptyTool, LastTool, MethodMonitoringTool, PrintTool, SyncTool, ThreadLocalTool
public abstract class Tool
extends Object

The superclass of all analysis Tools. To create a new tool:

  • Subclass this class.
  • Override event handlers that you care about.
  • If you want an abbreviation for the command line, add an @Abbrev("...") annotation to the class declaration (as shown in the example tools) and rerun ant. RoadRunner will then recognize that tool abbreviation.
  • (Optional) For improved performance, provide fast-path read/write methods: 
      
                        public static boolean readFastPath(ShadowVar, ShadowThread)
                        public static boolean writeFastPath(ShadowVar, ShadowThread)
    These methods are 'inlined' at each read or write in the target program. These methods return true to indicate that the event was correctly handled; if they return false, then the standard (and not inlined) 'access' method is called instead. There are corner cases where they cannot be used. Thus, design your tool to work properly, even if they are not inserted at an access site.
Event handlers are the methods of this class that take a single ...Event argument. Examples include access(), acquire(), preWait(), postWait(), etc. Each event handler is called whenever one of the threads of the target program performs the corresponding kind of operation.

Certain operations of the target program (join, notify, sleep, start, and wait) invoke two event handlers: one (such as preJoin) that is called right before that operation is performed, and a second (such as postJoin) that is called right after that operation is performed.

By default (if not overridden), event handlers simply call the event handler of the next tool in the tool chain.

Every memory location has an associated 'shadow location', of type ShadowVar. Most tools will subclass ShadowVar to store appropriate per-location information (such as the locks protecting that location, etc)

Always pass events along the tool chain, unless you are actively filtering them. To pass along, use super.X(). That idiom helps with debugging if all tools follow suit.

Constructor Detail

Tool

public Tool(String name,
            Tool next,
            CommandLine commandLine)
All tools are created by the RoadRunner infrastructure from the command line, based on @Abbrev("...") annotations. They are constructed prior to processing the items on the command line after the "-tool" option. name -- the print name of the tool next -- the rest of the tool chain commandLine -- the command line to which you may add new options

Method Detail

init

public void init()
Tool-specific initialization. Called after the entire chain has been constructed but before the target generates any events. All command line items will be processed at this point.

fini

public void fini()
Tool-specific shutdown. Called when the System is shutting down but before the xml dump happens. Be warned: worker threads could still be running and generating events while fini() runs.

printXML

public void printXML(XMLWriter xml)
Print out tool-specific log info at the end of the run.

create

public void create(rr.event.NewThreadEvent e)
This method of all tools is called for each thread creation event in the target program. Thus, thread creation events are not 'filtered' down the tool chain. By default, this method does nothing. You MUST pass this event along

stop

public void stop(ShadowThread td)
Called for each thread stop event in the target program. Thus, thread creation events are not 'filtered' down the tool chain. By default, this method does nothing.

access

public void access(AccessEvent fae)
Called for each access event (read or write) in the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

volatileAccess

public void volatileAccess(VolatileAccessEvent fae)
Called for each volatile access event (read or write) in the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

enter

public void enter(MethodEvent me)
Called for each method enter event in the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

exit

public void exit(MethodEvent me)
Called for each method exit event in the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

acquire

public void acquire(AcquireEvent ae)
Called for each lock acquire event in the target program. Re-entrant lock acquires are filtered out by RoadRunner, and do not cause acquire events. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

release

public void release(ReleaseEvent re)
Called for each lock release event in the target program. Re-entrant lock release are filtered out by RoadRunner, and do not cause release events. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

testAcquire

public boolean testAcquire(AcquireEvent ae)
RR Experimental Element. Do Not Use.

testRelease

public boolean testRelease(ReleaseEvent re)
RR Experimental Element. Do Not Use.

preWait

public void preWait(WaitEvent we)
Called right before each wait operation of the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

postWait

public void postWait(WaitEvent we)
Called right after each wait operation of the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

Called right before each notify operation of the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

Called right after each notify operation of the target program. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

public void preInterrupt(InterruptEvent me)
Called right before a thread invokes interrupt. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

interrupted

public void interrupted(rr.event.InterruptedEvent e)
Called when a thread recognizes it was interrupted (because it caught an interrupted exception, or because it tests interrupted() and gets true back).

classInitialized

public void classInitialized(ClassInitializedEvent e)
Called right after the static fields of a class have been initialized. By default, passes the event to the next tool in the chain.

cloneState

public ShadowVar cloneState(ShadowVar shadowVar)
Makes a copy of a ShadowVar. Called by RoadRunner as part of its handling of calls to "clone()".

advance

protected final void advance(AccessEvent ae)
A tool should should call this method when it no longer cares about the location touched by the access event. The ShadowVar will be initialized by the next tool in the chain, and so subsequent AccessEvents passed to this tool's access method should then be dispatched to the next tool in the chain.

makeShadowVar

public ShadowVar makeShadowVar(AccessEvent ae)
Return a fresh variable state for this tool for the location being accessed. Will be called only once per location per tool, when the previous tool calls advance() to indicate that it is no longer interested in owning the location

toString

public String toString()
The name of this tool. Used in auto-generated help information.

Overrides:
toString in class Object

toChainString

public String toChainString()
Generates a String representation of the entire tool chain. No need for tools to override.

accept

public void accept(rr.tool.ToolVisitor t)
RoadRunner internal method. "Visitor"-like pattern for tool chains. Applies t.apply(tool) to each tool in the chain.

hasFPMethod

public boolean hasFPMethod(boolean isWrite)
RR Internal Element. Do Not Use.

addMetaDatListener

protected final void addMetaDatListener(MetaDataInfoVisitor visitor)
Add a listener to be notified about class meta data as it is loaded by RoadRunner.

makeThreadDecoration

protected final <T extends Serializable> Decoration<ShadowThread,T> makeThreadDecoration(String name,
                                                                                         T initial)
Create the simplest kind of decoration on ThreadStates. Use the ShadowThread.makeDecoration method if you need more control.

makeLockDecoration

protected final <T extends Serializable> Decoration<ShadowLock,T> makeLockDecoration(String name,
                                                                                     T initial)
Create the simplest kind of decoration on ShadowLocks. Use the ShadowLock.makeDecoration method if you need more control.
